responses: Back when I ran HR, I thought I'd seen everything. But watching people build something from scratch? That's real power.
You were in HR? Must've been a nightmare.
Depends on the company. Mine was all spreadsheets and fake smiles. So I left.
And now you're just… hanging out in the park?
Best place to spot future leaders. Like you.
You know what I hated most? Watching great people get crushed by bad systems. That's why I'm rooting for you.
Thanks… I think I needed that.
I've seen talent wasted. You've got the guts to build a place where that doesn't happen.
Trying. But it's a lot to manage.
Just don't forget: systems serve people. Not the other way around.
After I quit, I lived in my car for a while. Made ramen on a camping stove. People started buying it. That's how I started again.
You're kidding. That's amazing.
Truth. No kitchen, no permits, just hunger and hope.
Guess you were doing ghost kitchens before it was cool.
Ha! With real ghosts. And no heat.
You're starting to see it, huh? The difference between someone who can grow, and someone who wants to.
Hiring's harder than I thought.
Because you care. Most bosses don't.
Still make mistakes though.
Good. Mistakes teach. Egos don't.
You don't run a noodle bar. You run a people bar. Keep them fed, and they'll carry you to the stars.
I think I finally get it.
Then you're ahead of 90% of managers already.
So… ramen is just the bait?
Exactly. And you're cooking up a revolution.
You run deliveries too? Back in my day, we dodged more potholes than customers.
You used to deliver noodles?
Fastest in town. Rain, wind, protests—you name it.
Bet your reflexes are still sharp.
They better be. I still ride like I've got soup to save.
Want a trick? Always tilt the bowl just a little uphill. Less slosh.
That actually works?
Trust me, customers don't like broth in the bag.
Noted. You should write a book.
I've got a title: 'The Zen of Zip'.
I once had to deliver during a typhoon. Helmet full of rain, brakes gone. Made it anyway.
You're serious?!
They still tipped. Said it was the warmest soup they'd had all year.
That's wild. You ever thought of quitting?
Yeah. But I love the chase.
Delivery's like life—balance speed and control, or spill everything.
So… I shouldn't boost around corners?
Only if you like soggy noodles.
Right. Ride smooth, serve better.
Now you're speaking my language.
You're making good runs. I see fewer spills. Cleaner reviews.
I'm learning from the best.
Keep your wheels aligned and your mind calm.
Soup first. Ego later.
Exactly. Now get moving.
Debate is just combat without fists. You ever shout numbers at someone until they give you money?
Not… exactly?
Then you've never pitched right. Let me show you how to strike.
Sounds intense.
Investor meetings are. But fun, if you've got nerve.
You don't win with volume. You win with rhythm. Speak like waves crashing, not like a faucet leaking.
So… prepare my rhythm?
More like, feel it. Be unexpected. Be sharp.
And don't leak, got it.
Heh. Good start.
Let's practice. I say 'Your business is unstable.' You say?
'And yet, profitable every cycle. Want in or out?'
Nice. Flip the pressure. Control the flow.
You do this for fun?
Winning is fun.
Debaters fear silence. Use it. A pause is a blade.
Wait... so say less?
Exactly. Make them lean in, then strike.
I'll sharpen my silence.
That's the spirit.
Now, you're dangerous. Calm, precise… loud only when it counts.
I think I'm finally ready for the next investor clash.
Then go make them tremble. And maybe… buy me dinner after.
Deal. If I survive.
You will.
You look like a guy running on fumes. Sit down. I brought tea.
Do I really look that bad?
Worse. You blink like your brain's buffering.
So, what... you're a therapist now?
Burnout specialist. And ramen fan.
People think rest is optional. It's not. You wouldn't let your noodles boil dry, right?
Point taken.
You've got ambition, but your brain needs oxygen too.
So I just… sit?
Start there.
I once worked with someone who never stopped. Perfect numbers. Until he didn't show up one day.
What happened?
They called it 'a personal break.' I call it damage ignored too long.
You think I'm close to that?
Closer than you think.
Sit with silence. It tells you more than noise ever will.
You sound like a monk.
I'm just someone who broke once, then learned to bend.
Guess I'm still learning.
Then you're doing fine.
I can't stop the chaos. But I can help you find stillness in motion.
That sounds… poetic.
It's practical. Breathe. Sleep. Let go of perfection.
I'll try.
That's enough.
This place is chaos. Beautiful, expensive chaos.
You shop here a lot?
Only for deals. And wisdom. These aisles tell stories, if you listen.
Right... noodles and enlightenment.
Same thing.
People forget that money leaks through the floor if you don't seal it.
You mean like… maintenance?
I mean like poor thinking. But yes. Fix your thinking, fix your bills.
So, budgeting is a philosophy?
Everything is.
Once had a student blow $10k on gold-plated napkin holders. He's bankrupt now. Still has the napkins though.
Ouch.
They were beautiful. Useless, but beautiful.
Note to self: no luxury chopsticks.
Unless they boost morale. Maybe.
Cut what doesn't add value. Keep what sings. Even if it's a weird statue in the staff room.
I… don't follow.
You will. When you find what your team laughs at, you'll find what keeps them going.
So jokes are… assets?
The best kind.
People chase growth. I chase balance. Growth without balance? That's just fire.
But fire cooks ramen.
Until it burns it.
Touché.
You're getting it.
